title-group.article-title: Phenotypic profiling of cognitive impairment risk among patients with heart failure: a literature review of the usefulness of cardiac-related variables

author-notes.corresp: Corrine Y Jurgens, Stony Brook University, School of Nursing, HSC L2-246, Stony Brook, NY 11794-8240, USA. Email: corrine.jurgens@stonybrook.edu

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Mild cognitive impairment among patients with heart failure can be subtle. Heart failure-related variables such as ejection fraction, low systolic blood pressure and functional status are reportedly associated with cognitive impairment among heart failure patients. The purpose of this literature review was to examine the value of cardiac variables commonly assessed during heart failure-related hospitalizations for a phenotypic profile of the risk of cognitive impairment.

sec.title: Method:
sec.p: A literature review of primary research studies was conducted. Electronic databases (PubMed and CINAHL) were searched using the keywords heart failure, blood pressure, ejection fraction, functional status, and B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) in combination with the terms cognition, cognitive function, cognitive dysfunction, and cognitive impairment.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Thirty-seven studies met the inclusion criteria. Evidence supports the potential utility of lower ejection fraction, lower blood pressure and functional status and elevated B-type natriuretic peptide as a phenotypic profile for an increased risk of cognitive impairment.

sec.title: Implications:
sec.p: If the risk for cognitive impairment is suspected, specific evaluations of cognition can be performed. For community-dwelling heart failure patients with mild cognitive impairment, more intense interventions to support self-care, increased family involvement and more frequent follow up may be necessary.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Heart failure (HF) is a significant health problem in the United States with an estimated 5.7 million Americans currently diagnosed with HF.1 As it is the most common cause of hospitalization and rehospitalization in older adults, efforts to limit repeated admissions among community-dwelling patients include optimizing medical management and improving self-care.2,3 However, self-care is challenging for many reasons, including complexity of medical regimens and non-specificity of HF symptoms. Further complicating self-care capacity is the prevalence of cognitive impairment,4,5 reported as ranging from 25% to 80% in the adult HF population.5-7 The etiology of cognitive impairment in patients with HF is not fully understood, but is believed to be due to either a chronic or an intermittent decrease in cerebral perfusion as a result of a failing heart.7-9 Associated with decreased cerebral blood flow is a sympathetic nervous system response which attempts to compensate for decreased perfusion.10 Brain imaging of patients with advanced HF has shown significantly decreased gray matter in areas corresponding to important aspects of cognitive function; specifically, the frontal cortex and the area surrounding the hippocampus.11 The degree of cognitive impairment is highly variable, extending from sub-clinical to severe. The clinical criteria for those patients with subclinical or mild cognitive impairment include a reported decline in cognitive function over the course of a year, clinically measurable deficits in memory or another cognitive domain, absence of significant impact on daily activities and no signs of overt dementia.12 Although HF patients with mild cognitive impairment may be capable of doing many activities of daily living, capacity for self-care may be limited.9,12-14

Self-care is defined as a patient’s active involvement in the management of their disease.9,15 As described by Riegel et al., self-care is a naturalistic decision making process where people make decisions in their real world environments.2 Patients with HF need to make daily decisions about medications and dietary choices. In addition, patients need to recognize and make decisions in response to HF symptoms when they occur. Cognitive function consists of several domains including memory, language, attention, visual/spatial/constructional, psychomotor speed and executive functioning.6 Patients with deficits in cognitive functioning, particularly executive function, memory and attention, are at risk for poor self-care.9,15 Descriptions of the cognitive domains commonly associated with self-care are listed in Table 1, together with the tests used in assessing that domain. Impairments in these domains make it more difficult for HF patients to follow complex plans of care, such as medication management and appropriate dietary practices.15,16 In addition, deficiencies in these domains make it difficult for patients to identify symptoms and make complex decisions about management of HF exacerbations.9 Consequently, deficits in cognition in the areas of decision-making may compromise self-care. Cognitive impairment in this population can be subtle. However, reliable neurocognitive testing typically used to detect mild cognitive impairment requires extensive training and time.10,17 Conducting this type of testing in the context of hospitalized patients with HF is likely impractical in routine assessments. A reliable method of identifying patients at risk for mild cognitive impairment using common HF-related assessments has not been reported.

sec.p: HF-related variables such as ejection fraction (EF), low systolic blood pressure (BP) and functional status are reportedly associated with cognitive impairment among HF patients. These variables may provide a phenotypic profile of those at risk for cognitive impairment. Identification of readily available routinely assessed HF metrics would be an asset when planning interventions to support self-care (e.g. family involvement, time to follow up, dose of educational intervention). Accordingly, the purpose of this literature review was to examine the value of cardiac variables commonly assessed during HF-related hospitalizations for a phenotypic profile of cognitive impairment risk.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: Electronic databases (PubMed, CINAHL, Medline and PsychINFO) were searched using the key words heart failure, blood pressure, ejection fraction, functional status, and B natriuretic peptide (BNP) in combination with the terms cognition, cognitive function, cognitive dysfunction, and cognitive impairment. A hand search also was conducted on studies retrieved. The inclusion criteria were: (a) samples with HF patients, and (b) studies published in English reporting on relationships of the variables of interest. Studies reporting cognition as a predictor of mortality were excluded, as the purpose was to examine predictors or correlates of cognitive status. Years searched was not limited. Based on the literature to date, the most commonly reported HF-related variables studied in relation to cognition include severity of systolic dysfunction (EF), BP, functional status (e.g. New York Heart Association (NYHA) class) and cardiac-related laboratory tests. To support the reliability and validity of studies used for the analysis, the authors (CYJ and KMF) reviewed and selected studies by reviewing the abstracts first followed by review of the full text versions. Consensus was reached for all studies included in the analysis. Three hundred and six citations were evaluated for inclusion. Duplicate citations (n=150), non-research reports (n=20), studies not available in English (n=2) and studies without analysis of the variables of interest were excluded (n=97) (Figure 1). As this is a novel line of inquiry, extrapolating relationships between cognition and the variables of interest necessitated including some studies with small sample sizes of HF patients. Thirty-seven studies were identified for inclusion in this review. Levels of evidence were determined using the method outlined by Melnyk and Fineout-Overholt (Table 2).18

sec.title: Cognition and EF
sec.p: Left ventricular EF was frequently investigated (n=23 studies) in relation to cognition, as EF is a direct measure of the heart’s pumping ability (Table 3). Investigators hypothesized that a decreased EF would contribute to decreased cerebral perfusion, and ultimately cognitive impairment. A 2007 systematic review by Vogels and colleagues identified inconsistencies in the relationship between EF and cognitive impairment;5 however, more recent studies support this relationship.4,17,19-32

sec.p: Zuccalà and colleagues were among the first to investigate the relationship between EF and cognitive impairment.32 In a small study (n=57), patients underwent an extensive physical assessment. Cognitive status was assessed using the Mini Mental Status Exam (MMSE). MMSE scores <24 indicate impairment.33 A non-linear relationship between MMSE and HF was identified with patients having a low EF (≤ 30%) scoring significantly lower on the MMSE. Multivariate linear regression provided evidence of a strong correlation between the natural log of EF and MMSE scores (β=0.58, p=0.001). Although the association was significant, the study was limited by the small sample and use of a global assessment of cognition. The MMSE is reported to be inadequate in assessing mild cognitive impairment and does not evaluate executive function effectively.6,34,35

Additional studies (n=15) using neurocognitive batteries support a relationship between EF and cognitive impairment,4,17,19-31 whereas seven refute it.36-42 The largest study (n=1114) divided participants into five quintiles, based upon EF, with the lowest quintile having an EF <62%.27 Participants in the lowest quintile had statistically lower scores in the domains of memory (p<0.001) and visuoperception (p<0.001). Within the lowest quintile, 18% (n=41) had an EF <55%. Interestingly, individuals in the highest quintile, those with an EF > 73.19%, demonstrated statistically lower scores on memory tests (Logical Memory Delayed Recall p=0.031, Visual Reproduction Delayed Recall p=0.029), executive functioning (p=0.022) and visuoperception (p=0.015). This is the only study to date that provided evidence of a non-linear, U-shaped relationship between EF and cognition.27 Of the seven studies refuting a relationship between EF and cognition,36-42 the largest study (n=157)41 reported a trend toward a significant relationship (p=0.07).

Although supportive of our hypothesis of the relationship between EF and cognitive function, these studies have limitations. Sample size, sex and racial diversity varied greatly. Twelve studies were small, with samples of 100 or fewer participants.4,19,21,22,25,26,28,31,32,37,38,42 The mean age ranged from 49.2 to 77 years and most studies (n=15) were predominantly male (63%–93%).4,17,20-24,26,29-31,36,39,42,43 Finally, racial diversity was sparsely reported likely due to the geographic origin of some studies. Countries of origin for each study are noted in Tables 3 to 8. Studies including racial statistics were predominantly Caucasian (60%–87%).21-24,28,30,38 Therefore, generalizability of these studies is limited.

sec.title: Cognition and BP
sec.p: Variations in BP differentially affect both the survival and cognitive status of HF patients when compared with other cardiovascular diseases or healthy persons.44-46 Typically, elevated systolic pressure is associated with increased cardiovascular risk (e.g. stroke).47 However, among patients with HF, lower systolic pressure is reportedly associated with decreased survival.44,46,48 Furthermore, among patients with HF, studies suggest that lower systolic pressure increases risk of cognitive impairment.49-52 Several explanations for cognitive deficits among HF patients have been suggested. Cerebral hypoperfusion, chronic hypotension and excessive hypertension treatment are a few explanations related to BP in this population.5,50

Lower systolic pressure has garnered the most empirical support in relation to cognitive impairment among HF patients compared with other objective metrics. Eight studies examining BP in relation to cognition were identified (Table 4).39,49-55 Cognitive impairment was associated with lower systolic BP in four studies.49,51-53 Using a cut off systolic pressure of < 130, Zuccalà et al. reported systolic BP was associated with cognitive impairment in 26% of HF patients versus 19% in the rest of the sample (n=1583 HF patients and n=12,052 patients without HF).52 In a subsequent study examining correlates of cognitive impairment in hospitalized patients (n=1511), 35% of HF patients were cognitively impaired versus 29% of others.51 Cognitive impairment was associated with lower BP, increased comorbidity burden, anemia, abnormal electrolytes, hyperglycemia and hypoalbuminemia. The investigators used a brief screening tool reported to be reliable in detecting mild cognitive impairment in these two studies. Another study reported similar findings with lower systolic pressure correlated with HF but only in patients scoring below the MMSE cut off (<24).49 That is, although the MMSE is a global cognitive measure, lower BP may be useful to characterize cognitively impaired HF patients.

sec.p: The preponderance of evidence supports a relationship between lower systolic BP and impaired cognition, but two investigators refute this position.54,55 Both studies used neuropsychological batteries to assess cognition. Trojano et al. compared patients with moderate (n=149) and severe (n=159) HF with persons who were HF free (n=207).55 Abnormal cognitive performance on more than two cognitive tests (primarily attention and memory) was associated with severe HF, higher depression scores and hypertension. However, a clinical history of hypertension versus actual BP readings was reported. Hajjar et al. also reported elevated, not lower, systolic BP to be associated with a phenotype of worse cognition (executive function), slow gait speed and higher depression scores.54 The analysis accounted for variables known to affect cognition (e.g. age, education, gender). Interestingly, if the patient had HF, higher systolic pressure was not associated with the phenotype as described. Supporting differences in the effect of systolic pressure in the presence of HF, a small study (n=70) of healthy elders (e.g. excluded HF, other chronic illnesses) reported that elevated BP was associated with impaired executive function.45 Therefore, evidence suggests that specifically among HF patients, it is questionable whether higher systolic pressure and cognitive impairment are related.

Results were mixed in reports of diastolic BP and cognition. Two investigators concluded there was increased risk of cognitive impairment associated with lower diastolic BP.50,53 Qiu et al. concluded that HF and lower diastolic BP were additive in increasing risk for dementia and Alzheimer’s Disease in HF patients.50 Guo et al. reported that both lower systolic (<130) and lower diastolic BP (<70) were significantly associated with HF, limitations in activities of daily living and cognitive impairment in univariate and multivariate analyses of 1389 patients in Sweden.53 Cognitively impaired patients were three times more likely to have lower systolic BP and twice as likely to have lower diastolic BP. However, the relationship between HF and lower diastolic BP did not persist in multivariate analysis. Both aforementioned studies used the MMSE to assess cognition. Conversely, another study reported that higher diastolic BP was associated with better cognition in HF patients in a small longitudinal study (n=75) evaluating cognition at baseline and 12 months.39 The authors suggest that cognitive function is modifiable in HF patients. They hypothesized that effective HF management (e.g. leading to better BP control) potentially explained the relationship. Cognition was assessed at 12 months, but BP was not. Therefore, their hypothesis is debatable. Overall, support for the relationship between lower diastolic pressure and cognitive impairment is limited.

Limits to generalizability include samples primarily of White males. Only one study reported ethnicity (80% White).54 All other studies were conducted in Italy or Sweden and ethnicity data was not provided. Sample size and representation of both genders was adequate. Sample size ranged from n=515 to n=1583 with four49,51,52,55 of seven studies approximately 50% male. The mean age across studies was typically older (M=80 years) consistent with the HF population and ranged from 73.9 to 85 years. Overall, the relationship between lower systolic BP and cognitive impairment risk is persuasive.

sec.title: Cognition and functional status
sec.p: Functional status is routinely assessed in HF patients to determine response to therapies and monitor disease progression. Common non-invasive methods for assessing function include the NYHA functional class and the six-minute walk test. In clinical practice, the four-point NYHA class based on symptom burden is frequently used. Class I reflects no symptoms with typical activity, ranging up to class IV, indicating symptoms at rest. Importantly, functional status as measured by NYHA functional class is predictive of quality of life and survival.56-59 As cognitive impairment among HF patients is reportedly associated with symptom and disease severity,60 the literature was examined for the value of functional status in relation to cognitive impairment risk.

Worse cognitive function was associated with lower functional status in the majority of studies (11 of 15) reporting analyses of this relationship (Table 5).21,22,32,34,41,55,61-65 To assess cognitive function, cognitive batteries of varying depth were used in all but two studies.32,64 Functional status was assessed using NYHA functional class,22,32,34,36-38,55,63-65 timed walk tests61-63 and the Duke Activity Scale Index.15 Although none of the studies were randomized trials, the five studies with the largest samples support an association between lower cognition and poorer functional status.55,61,63-65

sec.p: Cognitive status may be confounded by several factors, including age, education, intelligence, depression and other chronic conditions. Appropriately, Trojano and colleagues55 accounted for several risk factors for cognitive impairment in a study comparing patients with moderate (n=149) and severe (n=159) HF with patients without HF (n=207). Higher NYHA class was linked to cognitive impairment with attention and memory domains mainly affected. In addition, cognitive impairment was more prevalent in those with two or more risk factors. Similar findings were reported by Pressler in a study comparing cognitive function between HF patients (n=249) and healthy (n=63) and medical participants (n=102).65 HF patients had poorer memory, psychomotor speed and executive function. Furthermore, HF severity as assessed by NYHA class was associated with memory, visuospatial ability, psychomotor speed and executive function. Age coupled with function was a factor as well. Older patients with more severe HF had poorer executive function. Using a two minute step test as a measure of function (n=145 HF patients), Alosco and colleagues reported a significant relationship between executive function and language.61 Similar to the work of Pressler and Trojano, several confounding variables were included in the analysis. In the Studies of Left Ventricular Dysfunction (SOLVD), higher NYHA class was associated only with slower psychomotor speed.63 Four studies refuted the relationship between cognition and functional status.36-38,66 Sauve conducted a case control study with 50 HF patients matched on age, IQ and gender with 50 community participants.38 Although severity of cognitive impairment and NYHA class was not statistically significant for the sample as a whole, the p value approached significance (p≤ 0.08). Furthermore, for NYHA class III/IV participants, NYHA class was associated with poorer learning curves and impairment of attention (p< 0.001) and memory (p< 0.001). In another small study (N=60) refuting a relationship between cognition and functional status (r=0.01, p=0.37)37 only 23.3% of participants had a MMSE≤ 24 despite a relatively low educational level in the sample. Therefore, the study potentially was underpowered for detecting a relationship between cognition and functional status. Finally, a study which excluded NYHA class IV patients and was limited to males (N=64) also reported no relationship between function and cognition.66 Overall, the literature to date supports the relationship of poor cognitive function and lower functional status.21,22,32,34,41,55,61-65

Limits to generalizability include samples of primarily samples of white males. Of the 15 studies reporting on functional status and cognitive impairment, only those conducted in the United States reported ethnicity ranging 67 to 97.4% white.21,22,38,61,63,65 Six studies had small samples ranging from 20 to 60 participants.21,22,32,34,37,62 Most studies had slightly more male participants than female (average 62%)21,22,37,41,61,63,65,66 with a mean age across studies of 63.8 ranging from 49.2 to 77 years. Despite these limitations, the studies with the largest sample sizes support the relationship between poor cognitive function and lower functional status.41,55,61,63,65

sec.title: Cognition and HF-related laboratory tests
sec.p: Congruent with the purpose of this review, laboratory tests routinely evaluated in hospitalized HF patients were examined in relation to cognition. Tests most commonly reported include BNP, tests of renal function and lipids. If evidence exists supporting the association of cognitive impairment with a laboratory test that is regularly monitored as part of standard HF treatment, identification of individuals at risk for mild cognitive impairment would be simplified.

BNP is a neurohormone released by the heart in relation to elevated intracardiac pressures or volumes. BNP is recommended in clinical guidelines to monitor severity of HF.67 Recent evidence suggests that pro-BNP, a precursor to BNP, may be a more reliable marker for HF.68,69 As a result, some clinicians are not routinely evaluating BNP. There are studies which deemphasize this relationship, however.70 Though not extensive, evidence to date supports the relationship between BNP and cognitive impairment (Table 6). Three studies looked at the relationship between these variables.40,43,64 Two studies used the MMSE to evaluate global cognitive function and reported that elevated BNP levels were associated with lower scores.43,64 Kerola used the MMSE as the only measure of cognitive function in a five-year study of a cohort of 303 dementia-free patients. Participants were divided into tertiles based on BNP levels. Forty-three percent of participants with the highest BNPs at baseline had HF. Regression analysis revealed a negative relationship between MMSE score and BNP level (β= −0.151, p=0.001) with higher BNP levels associated with lower MMSE. Furthermore, an elevated BNP was predictive of MMSE decline over time (β=0.14, p=0.019).64 In addition to the MMSE, Mauro added a small neuropsychological battery, assessing memory and attention, specifically.37 Although a correlation between MMSE and BNP (r=0.25, p=0.02) was identified, there was no relationship between BNP and the specific domains evaluated in this small sample (n=60). The largest study reviewed (n=313) evaluated specific cognitive domains and reported that elevated baseline BNP levels predicted lower scores for information processing speed (β= −0.158, p<0.05), memory (β= −0.165, p<0.05), attention and executive functioning (β= −0.279, p<0.05).40 Overall, the studies of BNP provide limited support for BNP as a marker for mild cognitive impairment risk.

sec.p: Although supporting BNP as a predictor of cognitive impairment, these studies are not without limitations. Sample sizes were broad, ranging from n=60 to n=313.40,43,64 Mean age ranged from 65.5 to 81.3 years,40,43,64 so generalizability to a younger population is a concern. Gender was inconsistent between the samples. One study was predominantly (73.3%) male37 whereas another was predominantly (74.2%) female.64 Racial composition of these samples was not reported in any of the studies. Accordingly, these limitations need to be considered before generalizations are made.

Renal function is routinely evaluated in patients with HF. Decreased renal function may be a sequela of prolonged HF or an adverse effect of HF medications. Findings regarding the relationship between renal function and cognitive impairment are mixed (Table 7). However, different measures of renal function and cognition were used, limiting cross study comparison. Four studies, with sample sizes ranging from n=57 to n=448, supported the relationship between renal function and cognitive impairment.17,20,32,64 Kerola et al. reported a significant relationship between creatinine clearance and MMSE score (β 0.182, p<0.001).64 In another study (n=207), global cognitive function was evaluated in HF patients awaiting entry to a heart transplant program. Worse renal dysfunction was associated with lower MMSE scores (r= −0.17, p<0.05).17

sec.p: Only one investigator refuted the association between renal function and cognition.34 Harkness and colleagues used the Montreal Cognitive Assessment tool (MoCA) in a small sample (n=44) of older HF patients. Investigators found no relationship between MMSE score and glomerular filtration rate (GFR).34 The mean age for these samples ranged from 53.3 to 78.6 years.17,20,32,34,64 Gender composition was inconsistent, with one study predominantly (87%) male whereas another was predominantly (74.2%) female. Race was not reported in these studies likely due to the geographic location of the studies (Canada, Finland, Italy). Although these studies show promise, these factors limit generalizability of the results. Overall, the strength of the relationship between renal function and cognition is less than certain.

Lastly, three studies with sample sizes ranging from n=57 to n=580 evaluated the relationship of lipid levels and cognitive impairment (Table 8).32,54,64 Similar to studies of renal function and cognition, lipids and cognition were measured differently between studies. Two studies examined global cognition using the MMSE.32,64 Kerola found no relationship between MMSE score and total cholesterol or low-density lipoproteins (LDLs). However, elevated high-density lipoprotein (HDL) was predictive of better baseline performance on the MMSE (β=0.174, p=0.001), but not decline in score over time.64 Zuccalà et al. evaluated total cholesterol in 57 patients with chronic HF and reported that lower total cholesterol levels were related to lower MMSE scores (r=0.30, p=0.02).32 Hajjar et al., by comparison, administered a short battery of tests to 580 participants to identify a phenotype for cardiovascular risk.54 The phenotype for cardiovascular risk as opposed to normal controls had slow gait speed, impaired executive function and symptoms of depression. Elevated LDL was associated with this phenotype but a correlation between LDL and executive function was not specifically examined.54

sec.p: The multiple variables evaluated in these studies limit our ability to compare them or make predictions about the population as a whole. These studies also are limited by age, gender and race. The mean age was older and ranged from 76.7 to 78.6 years.32,54,64 Contrary to most other studies, these studies were predominantly (64% to 74.2%) female.32,54,64 One study reported 80% of participants self-described as White.54 Race was not reported in the remaining two studies, again likely due to geographic location.32,64 Based on the limitations together with inconclusive results, generalizations about lipids and cognitive function cannot be made.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Based on our review of the literature, published evidence to date supports the potential usefulness of severe systolic dysfunction (lower EF), lower BP, lower functional status and elevated BNP as markers of a phenotype of increased risk for cognitive impairment. To the best of our knowledge, the proposed phenotype for mild cognitive impairment among patients with HF is novel. These objective cardiac variables are frequently assessed as part of treatment for HF and are more practical than extensive neurocognitive batteries for identification of mild cognitive impairment. Though not causative of cognitive impairment, they are possible indicators of patients who may have mild cognitive deficits that otherwise may not be identified. Relationships have been identified between cognitive impairment and other laboratory tests (renal function, lipid levels), but variability in the markers used makes it difficult to generalize regarding their reliability. Other factors reportedly associated with risk for cognitive impairment include increased age, lower education, depressive symptoms and male gender.6,8,51,65,71 All of these variables are simple to assess and may indicate the need for more comprehensive interventions to support self-care after discharge to home. However, it is important to acknowledge that without prospective testing, we cannot hypothesize as to the relative importance of each variable in the proposed phenotype for predicting cognitive impairment risk. The analyses and strength of the relationship between the variables of interest and cognitive impairment differed across studies limiting cross comparison. The majority of studies were descriptive in nature using case control or cohort methodology18 as opposed to evidence from randomized trials. However, descriptive studies are appropriate for examining the relationship between the proposed phenotypic variables and mild cognitive impairment risk.

The relationship between cognitive impairment and self-care has been identified.10,34 Once, or if, risk for cognitive impairment is suspected (e.g. HF patients with low EF, systolic BP < 130, low functional status, elevated BNP, low educational level and advanced age) specific evaluations of cognition can be considered. In the hospital setting, a brief reliable and valid screening tool is desirable. The MoCA can be completed in 10 minutes and does not require extensive training to administer.6,13 Scores range from 0 to 30 with lower scores indicating worse cognitive function. Scores < 26 indicate cognitive impairment. This tool is more sensitive to mild cognitive impairment in patients with HF.34,72 Furthermore, by decreasing the cut off to 24 for patients with cardiovascular disease, the authors report increased specificity without sacrificing sensitivity in this population.72

Cognitive impairment in HF patients can be subtle. The insidious nature of HF can result in an individual who is able to function normally in society but unable to carry out the more complex functions of disease management instrumental to self-care.5 When planning care, clinicians could consider the potential value of tests in the proposed phenotype, particularly in relation to discharge education and follow-up care. Should a patient admitted with HF meet this phenotypic profile, screening for mild cognitive impairment may be considered. Once cognitive impairment is established, early interventions such as family involvement, frequent follow-up and education can be incorporated into disease management. Tailored strategies may help patients manage their HF more effectively and ultimately reduce risk for repeated hospitalizations for symptom management.

sec.title: Research implications
sec.p: Studies in this review were typically composed of older adults, Caucasians and males. Research is needed with diverse samples to confirm the phenotype. Although suggestive of associations with cognitive impairment, research investigating HF-related laboratory tests is by no means comprehensive. Only three studies evaluating BNP and cognitive impairment were identified. In addition, studies investigating renal function and lipids used different markers. Standardization of variables would strengthen the argument in favor of these indicators of risk for cognitive impairment. This literature review indicates a potential phenotype for mild cognitive impairment risk for patients with HF. However, prospective research evaluating the effectiveness of HF severity (EF), lower systolic BP, functional status and HF-related laboratory tests as markers is needed to support or refute the phenotype. Finally, prospective studies are needed to examine the relative value of each marker and determine meaningful parameters.
